item.text: During Jehoiakim’s reign, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked. Jehoiakim was his subject for three years, but then he rebelled against him.

The Lord sent against him Babylonian, Syrian, Moabite, and Ammonite raiding bands; he sent them to destroy Judah, just as in the Lord’s message that he had announced through his servants the prophets.
Just as the Lord had announced, he rejected Judah because of all the sins that Manasseh had committed.
Because he killed innocent people and stained Jerusalem with their blood, the Lord was unwilling to forgive them.
The rest of the events of Jehoiakim’s reign and all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.

<st data-num="03079" class="">He</st> <st data-num="07901 05973 01">passed away</st><n id="1" /> and his <st data-num="01121" class="">son</st> <st data-num="03078" class="">Jehoiachin</st> <st data-num="08478" class="">replaced</st> him as <st data-num="04427" class="">king</st>.

The king of Egypt did not march out from his land again, for the king of Babylon conquered all the territory that the king of Egypt had formerly controlled between the Stream of Egypt and the Euphrates River.
Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother was Nehushta the daughter of Elnathan, from Jerusalem.
He did evil in the sight of the Lord as his ancestors had done.
At that time the generals of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon marched to Jerusalem and besieged the city.

<st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="05019" class="">Nebuchadnezzar</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">came</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="05892" class="">city</st> while his <st data-num="05650" class="">generals</st> were <st data-num="06696 05921">besieging</st> it.

<st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="03078" class="">Jehoiachin</st> of <st data-num="03063" class="">Judah</st>, <st data-num="01931" class="">along</st> with his <st data-num="0517" class="">mother</st>, his <st data-num="05650" class="">servants</st>, his <st data-num="08269" class="">officials</st>, and his <st data-num="05631" class="">eunuchs</st> <st data-num="03318" class="">surrendered</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="05921" class="">to</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st>. The <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st>, in the <st data-num="08083" class="">eighth</st> <st data-num="08141" class="">year</st> of his <st data-num="04427" class="">reign</st>,<n id="2" /> <st data-num="03947" class="">took</st> Jehoiachin<n id="3" /> <st data-num="03947" class="">prisoner</st>.

Nebuchadnezzar took from there all the riches in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and of the royal palace. He removed all the gold items that King Solomon of Israel had made for the Lord’s temple, just as the Lord had warned.

He <st data-num="01540" class="">deported</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the residents of <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st>, including <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="08269" class="">officials</st> and <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="01368 02428">soldiers</st> (<st data-num="06235 0505">10,000</st> <st data-num="01473" class="">people</st> in all). This included <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="02796" class="">craftsmen</st> and <st data-num="04525" class="">those who worked with metal</st>. <st data-num="03808" class="">No</st> one was <st data-num="07604" class="">left</st> <st data-num="02108" class="">except</st> for the <st data-num="01803" class="">poorest</st> among the <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> of the <st data-num="0776" class="">land</st>.

He <st data-num="01540 0894">deported</st> <st data-num="03078" class="">Jehoiachin</st> from <st data-num="03389" class="">Jerusalem</st> to <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st>, along with the <st data-num="04428" class="">king’s</st> <st data-num="0517" class="">mother</st> and <st data-num="0802 04428">wives</st>, his <st data-num="05631" class="">eunuchs</st>, and the <st data-num="0193" class="">high-ranking officials</st> of the <st data-num="0776 01980 01473">land</st>.<n id="1" />

The <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> <st data-num="0935 01473">deported</st> to <st data-num="0894" class="">Babylon</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="0376 02428">soldiers</st> (there were <st data-num="07651 0505">7,000</st>), as well as <st data-num="0505" class="">1,000</st> <st data-num="02796" class="">craftsmen</st> and <st data-num="04525" class="">metal workers</st>. This included <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="01368" class="">best</st> <st data-num="06213 04421">warriors</st>.<n id="1" />
The king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin’s uncle, king in Jehoiachin’s place. He renamed him Zedekiah.
Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled for eleven years in Jerusalem. His mother was Hamutal, the daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah.
He did evil in the sight of the Lord, as Jehoiakim had done.
What follows is a record of what happened to Jerusalem and Judah because of the Lord’s anger; he finally threw them out of his presence. Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon.
